questions.text: Two days after delivery, a 4300-g (9-lb 8-oz) male newborn has difficulty feeding and has become increasingly lethargic. His cry has become weak. He was born at term. His mother has a history of intravenous drug use. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 70/48 mm Hg. Examination shows midfacial hypoplasia, diaphoresis, and tremor of the lower extremities. Macroglossia is present. There are folds in the posterior auricular cartilage. The left lower extremity is larger than the right lower extremity. Abdominal examination shows an umbilical hernia. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Neurologic examination shows decreased tone in all extremities. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium gluconate is indicated in cases of hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia. In hyperkalemic patients, calcium gluconate is used as a cardioprotective agent that stabilizes the cell membrane of cardiac myocytes to decrease the likelihood of arrhythmia. Patients with hypocalcemia benefit from direct elevation of serum calcium. Although both hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia can cause weakness, the patient's physical examination strongly suggests an underlying genetic condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroxine supplementation is essential for treating congenital hypothyroidism. This patient has some features consistent with hypothyroidism, especially umbilical hernia and macroglossia. However, the presence of other abnormalities, such as hemihypertrophy, hepatomegaly, and midface hypoplasia, is not consistent with congenital hypothyroidism. Most importantly, deficiency of thyroxine is very unlikely to produce an acute change in health, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of hypertonic (3%) saline would be the treatment of choice for severe hyponatremia, which often arises from vomiting or diarrhea without proper volume/sodium replacement. This patient has no history of significant volume loss. Moreover, the presentation of hyponatremia in neonates can be quite variable, with only the most extreme presentations requiring hypertonic (3%) saline. In these cases, patients appear acutely ill and often present with seizures, altered sensorium, and possibly coma. Given the lack of severe neurological dysfunction (e.g., seizure or coma), it is unlikely that this patient is suffering from severe hyponatremia.

D) CORRECT:

The congenital hyperinsulinism associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome can cause serious hypoglycemic episodes in neonates. In this patient, poor feeding likely further exacerbated the effects of hyperinsulinemia, ultimately resulting in signs of hypoglycemia such as weak cry, diminished muscle tone, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and tremor. Normalizing blood sugar levels through prompt administration of glucose should alleviate these abnormalities.

Patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at increased risk of developing nephroblastoma, hepatoblastoma, neuroblastoma, and adrenal tumors; serial screening with abdominal ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein levels is recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin and gentamicin are widely considered first-line agents to treat neonatal sepsis. Certain elements of this patient's presentation could raise suspicion of sepsis, including hypothermia, poor feeding, and lethargy. The presence of other abnormalities (hemihypertrophy, hepatomegaly, and midface hypoplasia), however, points instead to an underlying genetic syndrome that requires different treatment at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is used to reverse the effects of opioids, most often in cases of overdose. Neonates born to mothers exposed to opioids (either medicinally or recreationally) are at risk of overdose, which manifests with respiratory depression or apnea. This patient is tachypneic, making opioid overdose unlikely.
questions.hint: This newborn has macrosomia, macroglossia, midfacial hypoplasia, hepatomegaly, and hemihypertrophy. These features are suggestive of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

questions.text: A 4700-g (10.3-lb) male newborn is delivered at 37 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn appears pale. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows midfacial hypoplasia, infraorbital creases, and a large tongue. The right side of the body is larger than the left. Abdominal examination shows that the abdominal viscera protrudes through the abdominal wall at the umbilicus; the viscera are covered by the amniotic membrane and the peritoneum. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 48 mg/dL. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows enlarged kidneys bilaterally. In addition to surgical closure of the abdominal wall, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IGF-1 with elevated growth hormone levels is diagnostic of a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma, which can present as gigantism in children. It would be very rare, however, for a newborn to present with a pituitary adenoma, which would also not explain this boy's hemihyperplasia and omphalocele. Serum IGF-1 has no diagnostic utility in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Deregulation of the IGF-2 gene, however, is one of several genes implicated in the development of the syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Low free T4 levels would confirm hypothyroidism, which can be associated with macroglossia and abdominal wall defects (most commonly umbilical hernias). In congenital hypothyroidism, however, a newborn would not be expected to be large for gestational age nor have signs of hemihyperplasia or organomegaly.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels confirm the diagnosis of 21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency, the most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Although patients with 21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency can have hypoglycemia during a salt-losing adrenal crisis, other findings would also be expected (e.g., hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia). Furthermore, male neonates with congenital adrenal hyperplasia do not usually have any physical anomalies (i.e., macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, or organomegaly), which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A growth hormone-producing pituitary adenoma, which can result in organomegaly and a newborn being large for gestational age, can be diagnosed with a cranial MRI. It would be extremely rare, however, for a neonate to present with a pituitary adenoma. Cranial MRI has no diagnostic utility in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which is the most likely diagnosis here. A baseline MRI of the abdomen to screen for tumors should be considered and would likely be part of the workup for this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at increased risk for various tumors, including nephroblastoma, hepatoblastoma, and neuroblastoma. Abdominal ultrasounds with views of the kidneys are recommended every 3 months until 8 years of age to screen for these tumors. Additionally, serum α-fetoprotein levels should also be measured every 2–3 months until 4 years of age to screen for hepatoblastoma. Although measurement of urinary catecholamines has been proposed as a screening method for neuroblastomas, it has not been incorporated into most protocols.

F) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping can confirm the diagnosis of various genetic disorders, including trisomy 13 and trisomy 18, both of which can be associated with omphalocele. This patient, however, does not have other features of trisomy 13 (e.g., microphthalmia, polydactyly, and congenital heart defects) or trisomy 18 (e.g., prominent occiput, low-set ears, micrognathia, and rocker-bottom feet). In addition, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by deregulation of imprinting in certain genes, which would not be detected with karyotyping.
questions.hint: This newborn is large for gestational age and presents with facial abnormalities, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, organomegaly, and hypoglycemia. These features are consistent with the diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

questions.text:
You are called to a cesarean delivery, secondary to failure to descend, in a 37-year-old gravida 3, para 2 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation who has had an uncomplicated pregnancy and no significant medical history. A male infant is delivered with clear amniotic fluid and Apgar scores of 8 and 9 at one and five minutes, respectively. He weighs 5 kg.
On physical examination, he appears large and has a protruding large tongue, abdominal distention, and bilateral ear pits. You suspect a genetic syndrome.
Which one of the following characteristics is most likely to be associated with the genetic syndrome suspected in this patient?

choices.text: Increased risk for Escherichia coli infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome often present with hypoglycemia (related to hyperinsulinism), not hyperglycemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Agenesis of the corpus callosum is not usually seen in patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. It is, however, associated with several other syndromes, including Aicardi syndrome, as well as Andermann, Shapiro, acrocallosal, Menkes, and Mowat-Wilson syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no reported increased risk for sepsis in patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Children with galactosemia are at increased risk for developing Escherichia coli sepsis.

D) CORRECT:

This newborn has Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, a growth disorder with a range of features including macroglossia, creases or pits in the ears, visceromegaly, hemihypertrophy, and hypoglycemia. The diagnosis is made on the basis of observed clinical features and, in some cases, genetic testing.

Most individuals with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome have normal chromosome analysis and karyotypes — and no family history of the disease. In 15% of affected individuals, the syndrome is inherited through an autosomal dominant pathway. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome results from defective imprinting of genes controlling growth on chromosome 11p15.5.

Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at increased risk for developing embryonal tumors such as hepatoblastoma, Wilms tumor, neuroblastoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma. Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome should undergo abdominal ultrasound every 3 months until 8 years of age to screen for embryonal tumors. For early detection of hepatoblastoma specifically, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels should be monitored every 2 to 3 months during the first 4 years of life.

Hepatoblastoma is the most common pediatric liver tumor, typically occurring in children younger than 3 years, with a male predominance (2:1). Manifestations can range from an asymptomatic right-upper-quadrant mass to anorexia, weight loss, and abdominal pain. Diagnosis is made through elevated AFP levels and imaging (ultrasound or CT) that reveals a circumscribed, lobular lesion replacing most of the liver. Liver biopsy confirms the diagnosis, and treatment is usually resection followed by chemotherapy.

Key learning point: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with an increased risk of embryonal tumors such as hepatoblastoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Butterfly vertebrae are usually seen in patients with Alagille syndrome, a multisystem disorder with variable penetrance that is associated with mutations in the JAG1 and NOTCH2 genes. Other features of Alagille syndrome include characteristic facies, bile-duct paucity, chronic cholestasis, and abnormalities in the renal, vascular, skeletal, and ocular systems.
